Name: Maturational Changes in Anterior Cingulate and Frontoparietal Recruitment Support the Development of Error Processing and Inhibitory Control (Antistate)
Description: Documenting the development of the functional anatomy underlying error processing is critically important for understanding age-related improvements in cognitive performance. Here we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to examine time courses of brain activity in 77 individuals aged 8-27 years during correct and incorrect performance of an oculomotor task requiring inhibitory control. Canonical eye-movement regions showed increased activity for correct versus error trials but no differences between children, adolescents and young adults, suggesting that core task processes are in place early in development.
Acknowledgements: We thank Mark McAvoy and Abraham Snyder for support and development of functional data analysis procedures. Enami Yasui provided assistance with data collection. National Institutes of Mental Health (NIMH RO1 MH067924).
